response.improvementExplanation: This map() operation splits each line of the input file into a list of words. This operation can be performed more efficiently using mapPartitions() because it allows us to process multiple lines at once, reducing the number of function calls and improving I/O performance.
response.mapPartitionsEquivalent: mapPartitions(lambda partition: (line.split(",") for line in partition))
response.benefits: Reduced function call overhead, optimized I/O, and improved resource utilization.

response.improvementExplanation: This map() operation extracts the user ID and item ID from each line of the input file. This operation can be performed more efficiently using mapPartitions() because it allows us to process multiple lines at once, reducing the number of function calls and improving I/O performance.
response.mapPartitionsEquivalent: mapPartitions(lambda partition: ((line[0], line[1]) for line in partition))
response.benefits: Reduced function call overhead, optimized I/O, and improved resource utilization.

response.operation: map(lambda user_items: (user_items[0], sorted(list(set(list(user_items[1]))), key=lambda x: (len(x), x))))
response.improvementExplanation: This map() operation sorts the items for each user based on their length. This operation can be performed more efficiently using mapPartitions() because it allows us to process multiple users at once, reducing the number of function calls and improving I/O performance.
response.mapPartitionsEquivalent: mapPartitions(lambda partition: ((user_items[0], sorted(list(set(list(user_items[1]))), key=lambda x: (len(x), x))) for user_items in partition))
response.benefits: Reduced function call overhead, optimized I/O, and improved resource utilization.
